G.L. c. 212, \u00a7 4.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to G.L. c. 212, § 4, as the amount in controversy exceeds $50,000.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: Venue is proper in this Court pursuant to G.L. c. 223, § 1, as the underlying incident occurred in Pittsfield, Massachusetts, within Berkshire County.

*See Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693,.proposition: In Massachusetts, property owners owe a duty of reasonable care to all lawful visitors on their property or on abutting sidewalks, including a duty to avoid creating or permitting unreasonably dangerous conditions.
*See Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693,.support_reasoning: Mounsey v. Ellard abolished the invitee/licensee distinction in Massachusetts and imposed a general duty of reasonable care owed by property owners to all lawful visitors, which includes avoiding unreasonably dangerous conditions on the premises and, in that case, an abutting sidewalk. The quoted concurrence criticizes treating trespassers differently, but the majority opinion at 363 Mass. 693, 707 expressly adopts a unified reasonable-care standard for lawful entrants, so the case does support the stated proposition as to lawful visitors (though not as to trespassers).
*See Mounsey v. Ellard*, 363 Mass. 693,.relevant_excerpt: [From the majority at 363 Mass. 693, 707] “We therefore hold that the common law distinctions between invitees and licensees are abolished in this Commonwealth. The proper test of the occupier’s liability is whether, in the management of his property, he has acted as a reasonable man in view of the probability of injury to others … This duty of reasonable care is owed to all lawful visitors.”

*See Scholl v. United States*, 68 Mass..raw_text: *See Scholl v. United States*, 68 Mass. App. Ct. 811, 816 (2007).
*See Scholl v. United States*, 68 Mass..proposition: Defendant should have reasonably foreseen that permitting a visibly damaged and drooping branch to remain hanging over a public sidewalk created an unreasonable risk of harm to pedestrians.
*See Scholl v. United States*, 68 Mass..support_reasoning: The opinion provided concerns the validity of a guilty plea in a rape case and the standards for an intelligent and voluntary plea under Massachusetts criminal procedure. It does not discuss premises liability, foreseeability of harm from a dangerous condition, or anything related to tree branches, sidewalks, or pedestrian safety. Accordingly, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition about a defendant’s duty to foresee risks from a damaged, drooping branch over a public sidewalk.
*See Scholl v. United States*, 68 Mass..relevant_excerpt: “The intelligence of the defendant’s plea hinges entirely on the third basis for intelligence: the defendant’s admission to facts recited during the colloquy. … Here, the prosecutor’s factual recitation and the defendant’s acknowledgment that he committed the acts detailed therein were sufficient to constitute an admission to the ‘unexplained elements’ and establish that the defendant’s plea to rape was intelligent.”

*See Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389.raw_text: *See Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389 Mass. 47, 57 (1983).
*See Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389.proposition: Defendant’s breach of duty was the direct and proximate cause of Plaintiff’s injuries.
*See Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389.support_reasoning: This is a dissenting opinion arguing that the evidence did NOT warrant a finding that defendants’ negligence was the proximate cause of plaintiff’s injury. The judge concludes that causation is speculative and that defendants were entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Thus, this text refutes rather than supports the proposition that defendant’s breach of duty was the direct and proximate cause of plaintiff’s injuries.
*See Mullins v. Pine Manor College*, 389.relevant_excerpt: “Therefore, the plaintiff failed to show that the defendants’ negligent failure to exclude possible intruders from the plaintiff’s dormitory proximately caused her injury. … In my opinion the plaintiff failed to introduce sufficient evidence to warrant a finding that action or inaction of the defendants was the proximate cause of her injury, and the defendants were entitled to directed verdicts and judgments in their favor.”

*See Gage v. City of Westfield*, 26 Mass.raw_text: *See Gage v. City of Westfield*, 26 Mass. App. Ct. 681, 683 (1988).
*See Gage v. City of Westfield*, 26 Mass.proposition: As a result of Defendant’s negligence, Plaintiff suffered physical injuries, incurred medical expenses, lost wages, and endured pain and suffering.
*See Gage v. City of Westfield*, 26 Mass.support_reasoning: The opinion deals with wrongful death and conscious pain and suffering claims arising from a fatal railroad accident, focusing on governmental immunity, the railroad exception in the wrongful death statute, and standards of negligence versus recklessness. It does not discuss a living plaintiff’s recovery of medical expenses, lost wages, or compensatory damages for pain and suffering stemming from physical injury. Because the case concerns only death and punitive damages, it does not provide authority for the proposition that, due to negligence, a plaintiff suffered physical injuries, incurred medical expenses, lost wages, and endured pain and suffering.
*See Gage v. City of Westfield*, 26 Mass.relevant_excerpt: “Actions for wrongful death and conscious pain and suffering were brought by the administrators of the decedents’ estates… The motion judge ruled that the railroad was not liable to the plaintiffs under the Wrongful Death Act… [and] that the plaintiffs could not recover on a negligence theory for their decedents’ conscious pain and suffering… Accordingly, the entry of summary judgments in favor of the defendants is affirmed as to all plaintiffs and as to all counts, except that the cases against the defendants Conrail and George Munger may stand for trial on the claims for punitive damages…”

*See Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 31.proposition: But for Defendant’s negligence in failing to address the hazardous condition of the tree branch, Plaintiff would not have sustained her injuries on July 15, 2023.
*See Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 31.support_reasoning: The proposition is a standard factual ‘but for’ negligence statement about a hazardous tree branch in 2023. Kent v. Commonwealth concerns governmental immunity, ‘original cause’ under G.L. c. 258, § 10(j), and proximate cause in the context of a parole decision made years before a shooting. While Kent discusses causation concepts, it does not involve premises liability, hazardous conditions like tree branches, or the specific but-for formulation claimed, so it does not meaningfully support that proposition.
*See Kent v. Commonwealth*, 437 Mass. 31.relevant_excerpt: “[O]ne cannot be held liable for negligent conduct unless it is causally related to injury of the plaintiff… In addition to being the cause in fact of the injury, the plaintiff must show that the negligent conduct was a proximate or legal cause of the injury as well… Whether negligent conduct is the proximate cause of an injury depends not on factual causation, but rather on whether the injury to the plaintiff was a foreseeable result of the defendant’s negligent conduct.” (Kent, 437 Mass. at 320-21).

*See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457.proposition: Plaintiff’s injuries and damages were a foreseeable result of Defendant’s failure to act with reasonable care.
*See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly adopts a general premises-liability standard requiring landowners to act as a reasonable person in light of the likelihood and seriousness of injury, and it frames liability in terms of foreseeable harm to lawful visitors from snow and ice hazards. While the case is primarily about abolishing the natural/unnatural accumulation distinction, the court’s articulation of the governing standard presupposes that injuries from failing to exercise reasonable care in snow and ice removal are foreseeable harms for which defendants may be liable. The opinion does not discuss the particular plaintiff’s injuries as having been found foreseeable on the facts, but it clearly recognizes foreseeability of such injuries as part of the negligence standard.
*See Papadopoulos v. Target Corp.*, 457.relevant_excerpt: We now will apply to hazards arising from snow and ice the same obligation that a property owner owes to lawful visitors as to all other hazards: a duty to “act as a reasonable person under all of the circumstances including the likelihood of injury to others, the probable seriousness of such injuries, and the burden of reducing or avoiding the risk.” … If a property owner knows or reasonably should know of a dangerous condition on its property, whether arising from an accumulation of snow or ice… the property owner owes a duty to lawful visitors to make reasonable efforts to protect lawful visitors against the danger.
